0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (immediate-release) 200 to 400 mg ORALLY every 4 hours; MAX 2400 mg/day
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (extended-release) 600 to 1200 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 2400 mg/day

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• cough/cold products should not be used in children younger than 2 years because of the risk of serious and life-threatening effects; guaifenesin is commonly used as an expectorant in combination OTC cough and cold products
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (12 years or older; immediate-release) 200 to 400 mg ORALLY every 4 hours; MAX 2400 mg/day
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (12 years or older; extended-release) 600 to 1200 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 2400 mg/day
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (6 to under 12 years of age; oral solution/soft chews/granules) 100 to 200 mg ORALLY every 4 hours; MAX 1200 mg/day
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (4 to under 6 years of age; granules) 100 mg ORALLY every 4 hours; MAX 600 mg/day
  • Expectoration of abnormal sputum: (2 to under 6 years of age; oral solution) 50 to 100 mg ORALLY every 4 hours; MAX 600 mg/day

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• children younger than 2 years; infant deaths and serious life-threatening effects have been associated with over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold medications; guaifenesin commonly used as an expectorant in combination OTC cough and cold products; avoid use
  • cough accompanied by too much mucus; use not recommended
  • cough, chronic or persistent, accompanying a disease state (eg, asthma, chronic bronchitis, emphysema, smoking); use not recommended
  • cough accompanied by fever, rash, or persistent headache; may be a sign of a serious condition; discontinue use and consult physician
  • cough that lasts for more than 7 days or comes back; may be a sign of a serious condition; discontinue use and consult physician
  • guaifenesin in combination with dextromethorphan; avoid concurrent use or taking within 14 days of MAOIs avoid concurrent (or within 14 days) MAOIs use when guaifenesin is taken in combination with dextromethorphan
  • may produce a color interference with certain clinical laboratory determinations of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) and vanillymandelic acid (VMA)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Guaifenesin is thought to act as an expectorant by increasing the volume and reducing the viscosity of secretions in the trachea and bronchi. Thus, it may increase the efficiency of the cough reflex and facilitate removal of the secretions ; however, objective evidence for this is limited and conflicting.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (immediate-release tablets) take with a full glass of water
  • (extended-release tablets) do not crush, chew, or break tablet; take with a full glass of water; take with or without food
  • (granules) empty entire contents of packet onto tongue and swallow; for best taste, do not chew
  • (soft chews) chew and swallow

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea or vomiting.
  • Patient should take drug with a full glass of water and maintain adequate hydration during drug therapy.
  • Instruct patient that guaifenesin in combination with dextromethorphan should not be used in patients taking MAO inhibitors.
  • Advise patients with history of cardiac disorder, diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, prostatic hypertrophy, or glaucoma to avoid guaifenesin in combination with phenylpropanolamine.
